Elliotte Harold wrote:
> Kevin Lawrence wrote:
> 
> 
>>"Social security number should match the pattern 999-99-9999. AB-1234-XY 
>>is not a valid social security number."
> 
> 
> You're still thinking like a programmer. 

Actually I was thinking like someone writing a quick example on a 
mailing list.

try this one instead :


if(! ssn.matches(SOCIAL_SECURITY_MASK) ){
   throw new InvalidDataException(Messages.format(MESSAGE, ssn));
}

The exception type communicates to the programmer. Any caller can handle 
the exception if it makes sense to do so.


If the exception makes it out to the user they see a message like :

"AB-1234-XY is an invalid social security number. Social security 
numbers contain exactly nine digits, and no letters. Please check the 
number and try again."


HINT : The constant MESSAGE is a key to a table of user friendly error 
messages written by a team of linguists with PhDs in error messages. I 
did not write the message, they did.

Someone, somewhere needs to write the code to validate a social security 
number. That someone will almost certainly be a programmer. The fact 
that the ssn is invalid needs to be communicated a) to code that calls 
the social security validator and b) to the user. Exceptions provide a 
handy-dandy way to do that.

The SocialSecurityNumber class will be used in 27 different applications 
and every one of those applications will want to validate ssns and 
provide a useful error message (hand crafted by a team experts). Why not 
put that code in one place.


My point is that if you were to assume that exception messages will 
always be useless (like the ones in the JDK) you wouldn't show them to a 
user. Contrary-wise, if you were to assume that all exception messages 
might be shown to the user, you would take the time to make them useful.


Kevin
